properties.media:imagetext:
October 15, 1937
DM 27/
PERSONAL AND CONFIDENTIAL
Mr. Harold M. Bixby
Vice President for China
Pan American Airways Co.
Manila, Philippine Isls.
Dear Mr. Bixby:
Your personal and confidential letter of October 7th
arrived on the same day with your cable $148 outlining your suggestions
for a resumption of cooperation with CNAC. As you will have observed
ve answered with commendable promptness approving your plans.
You will
probably be in Nanking by the time this letter reaches the Far East,
and so it is hardly calculated to be helpful but, as nothing is pre-
dictable in our business, I an sending it along to give you a little
background on our feeling here which may possibly come in useful.
Frankly I think you described your program perfectly
when you called it a forlorn hope and referred to it as visionary.
can hardly
believe for a moment that it will work out in actual
tice,
For it teems fore that the see reasons militate einst
it that forced us to drop out of the picture two months ago.
However,
you must have some good reason for feeling that the situation is more
hopeful nos.
Of course, if we can hold our position by sone tenuous
tie-up with our Chinese
friends it may be helpful when the day of set-
tlement arrives, but I recall your saying sometime ago that any effort
to cooperate or
conditions
participate in the operations of CNAC under present
night simply result in our being declared "in" when the
final probable debacle cones, making it even more difficult for us to
try to revert to a settlement on the basis of the status quo of August
thirteenth.
It seems to me
that in the end our settlement is very
likely to be arranged through some form of diplomatic claim, and I
doubt whether our chances there would be notably improved by our re-
entry
the picture at this time.
However,
the President feels that
from the lashington angle it would be a very good thing if we could con-
tinue to hold some sort of a position in China.
He also had in mind the possibility that we might work
out some further financing from the
Import and Export Bank.
This was
a new angle to me and apparently his thoughts in this line are based
on some very informal conversations
he had in Washington. Nevertheless
